birdInfo.description: This is an aquatic bird, most notable for its white head contrasting with its brown and black body.
birdInfo.habitat: Inhabits wetlands, lagoons, and freshwater areas in South America, the Caribbean, and Africa.
birdInfo.diet: Its diet includes aquatic plants, seeds, small invertebrates, and crustaceans.
birdInfo.reproduction: They build nests in vegetation near water or in low trees. They lay between 6 and 12 eggs, and both parents take part in incubation and care of the chicks, which are precocial and can swim shortly after hatching.
birdInfo.size: Approximately 50 cm in length
birdInfo.funFact1: The white-faced whistling duck forms noisy flocks, known for their repetitive and loud calls.
birdInfo.funFact2: Despite being an aquatic species, they are excellent flyers and often travel long distances in search of new bodies of water.
birdInfo.location: Lago de Las Garzas Ecopark, Universidad del Valle, Farallones Country Club
birdInfo.bibliography: Dendrocygna viduata (white-faced whistling duck) plays a key role in aquatic ecosystems by contributing to seed dispersal, controlling aquatic vegetation, and regulating invertebrates. It is also part of the food chain, acting as prey for predators and serving as an indicator of wetland health; its stable presence suggests a healthy environment, while its decline may indicate environmental issues.

birdInfo.description: This aquatic bird is distinguished by its reddish-brown plumage, bright red bill, and pink legs. Ducklings have unique yellow down with black markings and a gray to dark gray bill and legs.
birdInfo.habitat: It inhabits wetlands, lagoons, and bodies of water from the southern United States to Argentina.
birdInfo.diet: Its diet includes aquatic plants, seeds, and small invertebrates, making it an important contributor to controlling aquatic vegetation and seed dispersal in its environment.
birdInfo.reproduction: They nest in trees or on the ground near water bodies, laying between 10 and 16 eggs. Both parents care for the chicks, which can swim and feed shortly after hatching.
birdInfo.size: 3.5 inches
birdInfo.funFact1: The whistling duck is known for its whistling call, which it emits even during flight.
birdInfo.funFact2: They nest in tree cavities, adapting to a wide range of habitats.
birdInfo.location: Ecoparque Río Pance, Country Club, Farallones Country Club, Lago de Las Garzas Ecopark, Parque de La Babilla, Río Lilí-Ciudad Jardín, Universidad Javeriana Cali, Club Cañasgordas, Multicentro Park – Sirirí Route, Universidad del Valle, Vegas de Comfandi, Ecoparque Los Pizamos
birdInfo.bibliography: This duck is essential for maintaining wetlands, aiding in the dispersal of aquatic plants and regulating aquatic ecosystems.

birdInfo.description: This duck is perfectly adapted to living in fast-flowing rivers, using its webbed feet and diving ability to swim against currents. It has striking plumage, with brightly colored males and more subdued females.
birdInfo.habitat: In South America, in open areas such as grasslands, agricultural fields, river margins, and even urban areas. It adapts well to a variety of ecosystems, from wetlands to semi-arid areas, though it prefers areas near water.
birdInfo.diet: Insectivorous, consuming insects, worms, snails, and small invertebrates found in soil or wet areas. This diet helps maintain balance in insect populations in its habitats.
birdInfo.reproduction: They build nests on the ground, often in open terrain. They usually lay 3 to 4 eggs, which are camouflaged to avoid predation. Both the male and female aggressively defend the nest, even attacking intruders to protect their young.
birdInfo.size: About 50 cm in length
birdInfo.funFact1: It lives in mountain rivers with strong currents, making it highly specialized.
birdInfo.funFact2: Its ability to dive and swim against fast waters allows it to survive in a habitat that few other animals can inhabit.
birdInfo.bibliography: Merganetta armata impacts the ecosystem as a bioindicator of mountain river health, signaling clean and well-preserved waters. It also controls aquatic invertebrate populations by feeding on insects and larvae, helping to maintain balance in food chains. Its presence promotes the protection of riverine habitats, contributing to biodiversity conservation in high mountain ecosystems.

birdInfo.description: Recognized for its distinctive grayish plumage, black chest, and a pair of spurs on its wings, which it uses as a defense mechanism. Its sharp and repetitive call is also one of its distinctive signals, especially in dangerous situations.
birdInfo.habitat: Inhabits South America, mainly in open areas such as grasslands, agricultural fields, water body edges, and even urban areas. It adapts well to a variety of ecosystems, from wet areas to semi-arid zones, though it prefers areas close to water.
birdInfo.diet: Feeds primarily on aquatic invertebrates such as insect larvae and small crustaceans, making it an important regulator of these ecosystems.
birdInfo.reproduction: They build their nests on the ground, often in open terrain. They usually lay 3 to 4 eggs, which are camouflaged to avoid predation. Both the male and female aggressively protect the nest, attacking intruders to defend their offspring.
birdInfo.size: Approximately 37 centimeters long.
birdInfo.funFact1: The Southern Lapwing is known for pretending to be injured to lure predators away from its nest, a very effective distraction strategy.
birdInfo.funFact2: In addition to its defensive behaviors, the Southern Lapwing uses its loud voice to mark its territory, alerting other birds and animals over a wide range.
birdInfo.location: El Pondaje and Charco Azul Wetland, located within the city, in areas with aquatic vegetation. Lago Calima or in more rural and natural areas near rivers like the Cauca River or Hacienda El Paraíso. Laguna de Sonso, Buga.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Southern Lapwing plays an important role in the ecosystem as a biological controller. Due to its territorial behavior, it acts as a protector of its environment, alerting other animals with its call to the presence of predators or intruders.

birdInfo.description: Often found foraging alone in dense vegetation along bodies of water. Butorides striata breeds in habitats near water, facilitating food gathering for its chicks. During the breeding season, they form monogamous pairs that dissolve at the end of the period. Both the male and female participate in incubation and chick care, displaying biparental care.
birdInfo.habitat: Inhabits freshwater and saltwater marshes from eastern Panama to northern Argentina. It is solitary and perches in dense vegetation near streams, rivers, lakes, and estuaries. Also found in marshes, tidal zones, exposed reefs, dry lands, and wetlands like agricultural fields, rice paddies, and flooded pastures.
birdInfo.diet: Uses a variety of foraging techniques to catch prey such as fish, amphibians, insects, and crustaceans.
birdInfo.reproduction: A small heron with solitary habits. It breeds mainly in areas near water bodies, such as mangroves, rivers, or lagoons. These birds build nests in trees or shrubs using branches and other plant materials. Females typically lay 2 to 5 eggs, blue-green in color. Both parents share incubation and chick care until they are independent.
birdInfo.size: Between 35 and 48 centimeters long.
birdInfo.funFact1: Plumage variety: This species shows considerable variation in its plumage color, depending on the region they are in, from bluish to gray or even green tones, allowing them to blend better into their surroundings.
birdInfo.funFact2: Bait fishing: The Striated Heron is one of the few birds known to use lures to catch prey. It can drop small objects, like twigs or dead insects, onto the water's surface to attract fish and catch them.
birdInfo.bibliography: Butorides striata plays a crucial role in controlling populations of small fish and aquatic insects, helping maintain ecological balance and promoting biodiversity in its habitat. Additionally, as part of the food chain, it serves as prey for larger predators such as reptiles and raptors.

questions.questionText: What is the most surprising fact about cormorants' diving?
answers: A) They can dive up to 45 meters deep
B) They can fly while underwater
C) They store oxygen in their feathers

birdInfo.description: It is an agile and fast bird of prey with dark gray plumage and a black mask on its head. It inhabits savannas, grasslands, and open forests. It feeds on small birds, mammals, and insects, hunting in flight or on the ground. Known for hunting in groups and using abandoned nests of other birds as it does not build its own.
birdInfo.habitat: Found in South America, mainly in open areas such as wet grasslands, savannas, swamps, rice fields, and the edges of lagoons, ponds, and rivers; also inhabits forested swamps and streams. Usually near sea level. In urban areas, it is found along canals and ditches.
birdInfo.diet: Feeds in wet meadows and muddy areas, probing with its long, downward-curved beak. Its diet includes small beetles, crustaceans, worms, insects, and other small prey.
birdInfo.reproduction: Nests in groups, building nests in trees or shrubs, near water bodies. The nest is a platform of twigs and leaves. Females lay 3 to 5 eggs, which are incubated by both parents for about 21 days. Hatchlings are altricial, meaning they are born blind and featherless, depending entirely on their parents for food and protection.
birdInfo.size: About 45 centimeters long.
birdInfo.funFact1: Its beak allows it to search for food in mud and wet areas, where other birds cannot feed. The shape of the beak helps it find food hidden beneath the surface.
birdInfo.funFact2: The presence of Bare-faced Ibis in an ecosystem indicates good health, as it requires clean water and vegetation to thrive.
birdInfo.location: Wetlands like Charco Azul and Pance
birdInfo.bibliography: Its role as a scavenger helps clean the environment by consuming animals or invertebrates in the final stages of decomposition. This behavior is essential for maintaining balance in ecosystems.

birdInfo.description: White bird with a yellow bill and gray or black legs. During breeding season, adults develop golden tones on the head, chest, and back. This species is known for its association with large mammals, such as cattle, on which it perches to feed. It plays an important role in controlling insects and parasites. By feeding on insects and parasites found on large mammals, it helps reduce populations of these organisms in agricultural and livestock ecosystems. Additionally, it acts as a seed disperser as it moves through different areas.
birdInfo.habitat: Its habitat includes open areas such as grasslands, agricultural fields, wetlands, and edges of water bodies. Originally native to Asia, Europe, and Africa, it has successfully colonized the Americas and other regions of the world. It prefers wet or semi-wet areas where it can find both water and the presence of large animals.
birdInfo.diet: It is an insectivorous species, primarily feeding on grasshoppers, flies, crickets, ticks, and other small invertebrates found on the ground or on animals such as cattle. Its feeding strategy involves following large mammals to take advantage of the insects they stir up while moving.
birdInfo.reproduction: They nest in colonies, often sharing trees with other heron species. They build nests of branches where the female lays 3 to 5 eggs. Both parents incubate the eggs and feed the chicks once they hatch, which takes about a month to fully develop.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 45 and 55 centimeters in length, with a wingspan of 85 to 95 centimeters.
birdInfo.funFact1: It spends a lot of time in terrestrial areas and is commonly seen perched on large animals, such as cows and buffaloes, from which it obtains food.
birdInfo.funFact2: It is a highly adaptable species and has experienced rapid global expansion, colonizing new continents in less than 100 years, such as the Americas and Oceania.
birdInfo.location: Ecoparque Lago de Las Garzas, Universidad del Valle, Club Campestre Farallones
birdInfo.bibliography: By feeding on insects and parasites found on large mammals, it helps reduce populations of these organisms in agricultural and livestock ecosystems. Additionally, it acts as a seed disperser as it moves through different areas.

birdInfo.description: Phalacrocorax brasilianus, known as the biguá or neotropical cormorant, is a water bird from the Phalacrocoracidae family. It is distinguished by its shiny black plumage, hooked beak, and intense green eyes. It is often seen perched with its wings spread to dry them after diving for food.
birdInfo.habitat: It lives in freshwater and brackish bodies of water, such as lakes, rivers, swamps, and coastal areas from the southern United States to Argentina.
birdInfo.diet: It primarily feeds on fish, which it hunts by diving underwater. It also eats crustaceans, mollusks, and small amphibians. It can dive several meters deep, using its hooked beak to catch prey.
birdInfo.reproduction: It nests in colonies, usually in trees or shrubs near water. The female lays 3 to 5 eggs, which are incubated by both parents for 25 to 30 days. The chicks are fed through regurgitation until they are ready to fly.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 60 and 70 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Diving birds: Cormorants lack efficient uropygial glands, so their feathers are not waterproof, allowing them to dive more easily. However, after swimming, they must dry their wings in the sun to prevent cooling.
birdInfo.funFact2: Used in fishing: Historically, in some Asian cultures, cormorants were trained to fish with a ring around their neck that prevented them from swallowing the fish, allowing fishermen to collect the catch.
birdInfo.bibliography: The biguá plays a key role in controlling fish populations, helping to maintain balance in aquatic ecosystems. Additionally, its presence indicates good habitat quality, as it requires healthy bodies of water to survive.

birdInfo.description: It is a waterfowl species that inhabits wetlands, lagoons, and freshwater areas of the Americas and Africa. Its plumage is brown with lighter tones, and its long legs make it easy to move through water.
birdInfo.habitat: It primarily feeds on aquatic plants, seeds, and some invertebrates, contributing to ecosystem balance by dispersing seeds and controlling aquatic vegetation.
birdInfo.diet: It helps maintain ecological balance and serves as an indicator of water quality in these ecosystems.
birdInfo.reproduction: They nest on the ground or in vegetation near water, laying between 8 and 12 eggs. Both parents actively participate in incubation and care for the chicks.
birdInfo.size: Approximately 50 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: They emit a characteristic whistling sound, from which their name 'whistling duck' derives.
birdInfo.funFact2: They are highly gregarious birds and form large flocks during migration.
birdInfo.location: Humedal del Lago de las Garzas
birdInfo.bibliography: The presence of the Fulvous Whistling Duck in wetlands is an indicator of good water quality and ecosystem health. Their role in seed dispersion and control of aquatic vegetation is essential for maintaining the balance of these ecosystems.

birdInfo.description: It is a large and striking bird that inhabits tropical wetlands, distinguished by its peculiar bony horn on its head and the spines on its wings, which it uses as a defense. Its unique appearance and defensive behavior make it a fascinating and distinctive species in the habitats it occupies.
birdInfo.habitat: It mainly lives in wetland ecosystems and areas near bodies of water such as rivers, lakes, and swamps.
birdInfo.diet: It is herbivorous, feeding on aquatic plants, consuming leaves, stems, and shoots of plants that grow in or near water bodies where it lives, like grass and reeds. It also eats seeds from aquatic and terrestrial plants.
birdInfo.reproduction: They build their nests near the shores of wetlands. They lay between 2 and 6 eggs. The incubation period lasts approximately 42 to 46 days, and both parents take care of the eggs and chicks.
birdInfo.size: Approximately 84 to 95 cm in length
birdInfo.funFact1: Unique horns: This horn is unique to birds and is not connected to the skull, making it flexible. It gives the bird an unmistakable appearance.
birdInfo.funFact2: Spiny wings: These sharp spines are located on the wing joint and can be used for defense against predators or in territorial fights, providing them with a natural weapon.
birdInfo.location: El Pondaje and Charco Azul wetlands, located within the city, where there are areas with aquatic vegetation. Calima Lake or more rural and natural areas near rivers such as the Cauca River or Hacienda El Paraíso. Sonso Lagoon, Buga. Confirmed.
birdInfo.bibliography: This scavenger bird helps maintain environmental balance by cleaning the surroundings of dead animals, reducing the spread of diseases. By feeding on organic waste, it contributes to the natural decomposition of matter and promotes nutrient recycling in the soil, favoring the health of swamp and wetland ecosystems.

birdInfo.description: It is a medium-sized hummingbird with a unique pattern, many concentrate in flowering trees where they are aggressive and even territorial with each other. Both sexes fly for long periods, hovering and soaring far above streams and clearings, or launching from perches in the treetops; it collects foliage less frequently.
birdInfo.habitat: It inhabits humid and tropical mountain forests from Costa Rica to northern Peru, at altitudes ranging from 400 to 1,500 meters above sea level. It prefers shaded and densely vegetated areas, such as the understory of cloud forests and montane forests, where it finds tubular flowers for nectar.
birdInfo.diet: It feeds on nectar and small arthropods, visiting flowers from a variety of trees, bromeliads, shrubs, and heliconia.
birdInfo.reproduction: The nest is a soft and shallow cup made of light-colored plant fluff and spider webs. The female incubates and lays 2 eggs.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 12 and 14 centimeters in length
birdInfo.funFact1: Notable sexual dimorphism: Males have bright black plumage, while females have duller colors, which helps with camouflage.
birdInfo.funFact2: Acrobatic flight: They are capable of performing fast flights and acrobatic maneuvers, allowing them to defend their territory and easily escape predators.
birdInfo.bibliography: The hummingbird Florisuga mellivora is an important pollinator of tropical plants. By feeding on nectar, it transports pollen between flowers, promoting their reproduction and maintaining plant diversity in its habitat. It also helps control populations of small insects, which are part of its diet.

birdInfo.description: Distinguished by its all-black plumage, long tail, large beak, and distinctive call. During the breeding season, this ani lives in pairs or, more commonly, in larger groups of up to 17 individuals. It is best known for its communal breeding system, where several females often lay eggs and incubate them in the same nest.
birdInfo.habitat: Throughout its range, it occupies savannas, rural and suburban areas disturbed by humans, and secondary growth shrubs year-round. It is present near cow pastures, sugar cane fields, secondary moist forests, vegetation-rich fields, and roadsides.
birdInfo.diet: They are mainly insectivorous, feeding on grasshoppers, caterpillars, and moths, but also on small frogs and lizards. Fruit is an important part of their diet during the dry season.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 30 and 36 cm in length
birdInfo.reproduction: Depending on the group size, up to 36 eggs can be found in a single nest.
birdInfo.funFact1: Groups can identify two nesting sites and spend time at each, suggesting difficulty choosing; they may work on two nests simultaneously before deciding on the final one.
birdInfo.funFact2: Individuals in a group demonstrate a strong degree of collaboration and mutual assistance during nesting and hunting.
birdInfo.bibliography: The communal breeding behavior of the ani bird (Crotophaga ani) is unique among birds, as it shows social cooperation in raising chicks. This species often forms large groups of up to 17 individuals who share the responsibility of incubating eggs and feeding the chicks. This behavior enhances the chicks' survival by providing additional protection and food during critical development periods.

birdInfo.description: It stands out for its bluish-black plumage, long tail, and curved beak. It lives in family groups, displaying cooperative social behavior and helping to control insect populations.
birdInfo.habitat: It inhabits swampy areas and open spaces with low vegetation, such as rivers, wetlands, and grasslands, preferring high humidity regions near bodies of water.
birdInfo.diet: It feeds on insects, small vertebrates like frogs and lizards, and some fruits, searching for its food on the ground or low vegetation.
birdInfo.reproduction: It practices cooperative breeding, where several adults build communal nests and jointly care for the eggs and young. The nests are large and made of branches in low trees.
birdInfo.size: It measures 46 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: It has a unique social structure, living in family groups and practicing communal breeding, where several adults care for the young of the entire group.
birdInfo.funFact2: Its name 'ani' comes from the characteristic sound of its call, a repetitive and rough song it emits while moving through its habitat or communicating with its group.
birdInfo.location: Ecoparque Río Pance, Club Campestre, Club Campestre Farallones, Ecoparque Lago de Las Garzas, Parque de La Babilla, Río Lilí – Ciudad Jardín, Universidad Javeriana Cali, Club Cañasgordas, Parque Multicentro-Ruta del Sirirí, Universidad del Valle, Vegas de Comfandi, Ecoparque Los Pizamos
birdInfo.bibliography: Insect control: By feeding on a wide variety of insects, such as grasshoppers and crickets, it helps keep invertebrate populations in check, which is key for ecosystem balance. Seed dispersal: Although its diet is mainly insectivorous, it also consumes fruits, contributing to seed dispersal and aiding in plant regeneration in its habitat.

birdInfo.description: It has a generally green body; the male’s throat and chest are a brighter green. It also has a bright pinkish-red bill (with a black tip) and a bright reddish tail.
birdInfo.habitat: This species is common and widespread in non-forest areas, including clearings, gardens, forest edges, and some secondary forests. It prefers low habitats, with shrubs, and often visits feeders located in open areas with some coverage.
birdInfo.diet: Rufous-tailed hummingbirds feed on nectar and visit Heliconia, banana, and coffee flowers. Since nectar is low in protein, they also feed on small insects. This species is also a regular visitor to artificial feeders filled with a mixture of water and sugar.
birdInfo.reproduction: Nests have been reported in Colombia in February and August. Females usually choose small trees or shrubs as nesting sites, and they usually lay two eggs. The incubation period is 15 to 16 days. The chicks fledge around 18 to 22 days of age, though they do not become independent from their mothers until around day 58. The female takes on all parental care.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 9.0 and 10.11 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Territorial aggression: Although small, the Amazilia tzacatl is highly territorial and vigorously defends its nectar source from other hummingbirds and even larger birds.
birdInfo.funFact2: Ability to fly in all directions: Like other hummingbirds, this species can fly forward, backward, up, down, and even hover in place, thanks to the rapid speed of its wings.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Amazilia tzacatl hummingbird plays a key role in pollinating numerous plants. By feeding on flower nectar, it facilitates plant reproduction, contributing to the balance and plant diversity in its environment. It also consumes small insects, helping to control their populations. Its presence benefits both flora and other species that depend on pollinated plants.

questions.questionText: Why is the presence of Apodiformes birds important in an ecosystem?
answers: A) Because they contribute to rock erosion
B) Because they help spread plant seeds
C) Because they contribute to the control of insects and pests
D) Because they influence water quality

questions.questionText: What is a notable ability of swifts, a group within the Apodiformes?
answers: A) They can sleep at night hanging from their legs
B) Their nests are built on the ground to avoid predators
C) They can change the color of their feathers to blend in
D) They can spend months in the air without landing

questions.questionText: What peculiarity do swifts have regarding their life in the air?
answers: A) They only fly to hunt
B) They can sleep while flying
C) They only fly during the breeding season
D) They cannot fly long distances

birdInfo.description: Small hummingbird, generally bright green in males and with white underparts in females. Both sexes have white tufts on their legs (smaller in females) and a forked tail; males have elongated outer tail feathers, ending in bare shafts and racket-like tips.
birdInfo.habitat: Humid forest zone of the subtropical and temperate regions of the Andes. Found both inside forests and in open secondary forests. In Colombia, it is known to be found in both primary and secondary sub-Andean forests (below 2400 m).
birdInfo.diet: This species feeds on nectar from flowers visited by insects, mainly large bees, and bee-pollinated flowers, each flower containing a small volume of nectar with relatively high concentration.
birdInfo.reproduction: The nest is placed on horizontal tree branches at a height of 6 to 8 meters above the ground. Only the female incubates, and the incubation lasts between 16 and 17 days. The clutch size is 2 eggs.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 11-15 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Elaborate tail feathers: The male Booted Racket-tail is easily recognizable by its long outer tail feathers, with unique racket-shaped tips.
birdInfo.funFact2: Aggressive toward other hummingbirds: Despite its size, this species is known for being highly aggressive when defending its feeding areas.
birdInfo.location: Farallones de Cali, Rio Pance Eco-Park
birdInfo.bibliography: This hummingbird is an important pollinator of numerous plant species, facilitating the reproduction of plants that rely on animal pollination. By feeding on nectar and visiting a wide variety of flowers, it ensures the continuity of these plants, which are crucial to the biodiversity of the Andean ecosystem.

questions.questionText: How do Apodiformes, such as swifts, capture their food?
answers: A) They collect fruits from trees
B) They dig in the ground to find prey
C) They catch insects while flying at high speed
D) They hunt on the water surface

questions.questionText: What is the relationship between Apodiform birds and bodies of water?
answers: A) They are aquatic birds and swim to catch their food
B) They avoid areas near water
C) They only use bodies of water for nesting
D) They are found near bodies of water where they hunt flying insects

questions.questionText: Where do Apodiformes prefer to live?
answers: A) Open and high areas like mountains and forests
B) Deserts and dry plains
C) Dense tropical rainforests
D) Coastal aquatic areas

birdInfo.description: They are a captivating group of short-billed and long-tailed hummingbirds found in the humid montane forests of the Andes. This species is sexually dimorphic; males have a bright green crown and throat with exceptionally long and dazzling greenish-blue tail feathers. Females have a much shorter tail, a white throat with green spots, and a reddish-beige belly.
birdInfo.habitat: It is found in a variety of habitats, depending on the location and time of year. It is associated with subtropical and temperate forests, but can also be found at forest edges, semi-open areas of moist forest or regrowth, premontane areas, shrubs, clearings, pastures, gardens, and agricultural areas like coffee plantations, although it is rarely seen inside forests.
birdInfo.diet: This shade-loving hummingbird feeds in the understory, hovering over flowers. While acting as a pollinator, it sometimes steals nectar by piercing flowers. At higher altitudes, it feeds in the canopies of small trees and shrubs. It consumes nectar and arthropods.
birdInfo.reproduction: In Colombia, reproduction has been documented from February to October, but it is believed the species breeds year-round. The male participates in ritualized nest construction, the female sleeps in the nest every night, and she is the only one who incubates. The incubation period is 15 to 17 days, and they lay 2 eggs.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 16 and 19 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Long and striking tail: Males have an extremely long tail, nearly twice their body size, used in courtship displays.
birdInfo.funFact2: Feeds in flight: Like other hummingbirds, it mainly feeds while flying, allowing access to flowers inaccessible to other species.
birdInfo.bibliography: The hummingbird Aglaiocercus kingii is vital for the pollination of various plants in the Andean forests. By feeding on nectar, it facilitates pollen transfer between flowers, promoting plant reproduction and contributing to the ecosystem's biodiversity.

questions.questionText: What adaptation allows Caprimulgiformes to efficiently catch insects while flying?
answers: A) Long and strong feet
B) Curved and sharp beak
C) Large and wide mouth
D) Vibrant colored feathers

questions.questionText: How do Caprimulgiformes birds camouflage in their environment?
answers: A) Through their bright colors
B) By burying themselves underground
C) Through their plumage that mimics the surroundings, like leaves and branches
D) By placing themselves in water to blend in with the reflection

questions.questionText: What is one of the main adaptations of Caprimulgiformes for nocturnal flight?
answers: A) Plumage that changes color in the dark
B) Wings with membranes that reflect light
C) Eyes adapted to low light
D) Long legs that allow silent flight

birdInfo.description: It is a medium-sized brown bird with a long tail and a short, bushy crest. Its ventriloquial call is often heard in grasslands, though it is hard to locate. Both sexes look alike.
birdInfo.habitat: It inhabits open fields with scattered trees, shrubs, wet grasslands, and clearings in wooded areas.
birdInfo.diet: It mainly feeds on insects like grasshoppers and beetles, foraging on the ground or low vegetation. It is a solitary, elusive bird, easier to hear than to see.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 26.0 - 29.0 cm in length.
birdInfo.reproduction: The Striped Cuckoo is a brood parasite that lays its eggs in the nests of other birds, such as pipits and wrens. Incubation lasts 15 to 16 days, and care is provided by the host species.
birdInfo.funFact1: The young cuckoo kills its nestmates shortly after hatching with its hooked beak and is raised alone in the host's nest. It leaves the nest when it is 16 to 18 days old.
birdInfo.funFact2: The ventriloquial call of Tapera naevia is very distinctive and can easily confuse people, making it hard to locate the bird as it usually sings from hidden spots in the vegetation.
birdInfo.location: Ecoparque Lago de Las Garzas, Universidad del Valle, Club Campestre Farallones
birdInfo.bibliography: Tapera naevia helps control insect populations by feeding primarily on them, contributing to ecological balance. It also aids in seed dispersal and vegetation regeneration by consuming fruits.

questions.questionText: What migratory behavior do some Cuculiformes species, like the Common Cuckoo, exhibit?
answers: A) They are sedentary birds that do not migrate
B) They only move within the same continent
C) They migrate between the Arctic and the Antarctic
D) They migrate between Europe or Asia and Africa in search of better conditions

questions.questionText: What is the function of vocalizations in Cuculiformes?
answers: A) Only for communication with their chicks
B) For communication and courtship, as well as territorial defense
C) Only to alert about predators
D) To mimic the sounds of other animals

questions.questionText: What behavior is characteristic of many Cuculiformes species in relation to reproduction?
answers: A) They build nests in tree cavities
B) They lay their eggs in other birds' nests for them to be incubated
C) They raise their eggs in nests built on the ground
D) They prefer to incubate their eggs in floating nests

birdInfo.description: This bird is seen gliding from tree to tree or hopping from branch to branch in search of arthropods. Its movements resemble those of squirrels before it glides down. Its plumage is reddish-brown above, with a beige throat and chest, and light gray belly. Its long tail is reddish on top and blackish with white tips underneath.
birdInfo.habitat: It inhabits humid to semi-humid forests, dry forests, forest edges, secondary forests, scattered trees in open fields, mangroves, flooded forests, advanced secondary growth forests, grasslands with scattered trees, coffee plantations, and near watercourses in dry areas.
birdInfo.diet: It primarily feeds on insects like caterpillars, moths, grasshoppers, beetles, wasps, bees, large ants, cicadas, hemipterans, spiders, small lizards, some fruits, and small frogs.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 40.0 and 46.0 cm in length.
birdInfo.reproduction: Nests are built in trees or in low, dense vegetation. The clutch typically consists of two eggs. The eggs are chalky white with no markings; both sexes incubate. The incubation period is 18 to 19 days. Both sexes provide for the chicks.
birdInfo.funFact1: Parents maintain a fairly clean nest by removing feces and bringing fresh leaves.
birdInfo.funFact2: Squirrel Cuckoos are almost always solitary or in pairs. They may follow mixed-species flocks but often forage away from them.
birdInfo.location: Ecoparque Lago de Las Garzas, Universidad del Valle, Club Campestre Farallones
birdInfo.bibliography: Piaya cayana, or the common cuckoo, has important ecological effects, such as controlling insect populations by feeding on arthropods. Its presence indicates the health of the ecosystem, as it is sensitive to changes in food availability. It also influences food chain dynamics and contributes to seed dispersal by occasionally consuming fruits, aiding in vegetation regeneration.

questions.questionText: What is a characteristic ability of hummingbirds that differentiates them from other birds?
answers: A) They can sleep while flying
B) They can swim long distances
C) They can fly in all directions, including stationary flight (hovering)
D) They can stay underwater for long periods

questions.questionText: Where do Apodiformes birds prefer to inhabit?
answers: A) Open and high areas such as mountains and forests
B) Deserts and dry plains
C) Dense tropical forests
D) Coastal aquatic zones

questions.questionText: What is the relationship of Apodiformes birds with bodies of water?
answers: A) They are aquatic birds and swim to catch their food
B) They avoid areas near water
C) They only use bodies of water for nesting
D) They are found near bodies of water where they hunt flying insects

birdInfo.description: The Black-throated Mango is a notable hummingbird for its mostly green plumage and characteristic black throat and underparts. Both sexes have slightly curved bills. It is the most common and widely distributed member of its genus.
birdInfo.habitat: This species inhabits open vegetation with scattered shrubs and trees, in various humid and dry habitats, including gardens, parks, agricultural plantations, riverbanks, roadsides, and fragmented and degraded landscapes.
birdInfo.diet: This hummingbird feeds on nectar from tall trees like eucalyptus and hunts insects in the treetops, including ants, bark lice, and small beetles. It occasionally captures insects lower or on prey-rich surfaces.
birdInfo.reproduction: The female builds the nest with seed fluff and spider webs in 4 to 11 days. She lays two eggs 48 hours apart, usually in the morning. Incubation lasts 13 to 18 days.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 11 and 12 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Sexual dimorphism: Males have dark, iridescent plumage, while females are duller and less brightly colored.
birdInfo.funFact2: Migratory flights: Although not all populations migrate, some individuals of this species make seasonal movements in search of food.
birdInfo.bibliography: The hummingbird Anthracothorax nigricollis plays an important role in plant pollination, helping with the reproduction of various plant species. Additionally, by consuming small insects, it contributes to controlling their populations.

questions.questionText: What adaptation allows Caprimulgiformes to be efficient in catching insects while flying?
answers: A) Long and strong feet
B) Curved and sharp beak
C) Large and wide mouth
D) Vibrant colored feathers

questions.questionText: What type of habitat is preferred by Caprimulgiformes for nesting?
answers: A) Urban areas with tall buildings
B) Arid deserts with little vegetation
C) Open grassland areas without cover
D) Dense forests and scrublands

questions.questionText: What is the primary food source for Caprimulgiformes birds?
answers: A) Nocturnal insects such as moths and mosquitoes
B) Fruits and seeds
C) Small mammals
D) Fish and crustaceans

birdInfo.description: This species often sleeps on tree branches or on the ground and has experienced a 50% decline in Canada over the last three generations, being classified as threatened. This could be due to predation, pesticide use, and habitat loss.
birdInfo.habitat: It actively pursues flying insects in flight, often catching those attracted to streetlights and other bright lights.
birdInfo.diet: This bird feeds on large insects during the night and is seen flying near bright lights in places like supermarkets and ball games. Its flight is distinctive, with V-shaped wings, and it hunts insects at dawn and dusk in urban and rural areas.
birdInfo.reproduction: Incubation is generally performed by the female, although sometimes the male participates. She leaves the eggs or chicks unsupervised at night and usually lays two eggs on bare ground, sometimes nesting on gravel roofs.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 22 and 24 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Long migration: These birds make massive migrations, traveling from North America to South America, covering great distances during the winter.
birdInfo.funFact2: Twilight flights: The Chordeiles minor is most active at dawn and dusk, being one of the few birds that hunt insects in flight during those hours.
birdInfo.bibliography: This bird is crucial for controlling populations of flying insects, as it primarily feeds on them during its twilight and nocturnal flights. This helps maintain ecological balance by reducing mosquito and other insect pests, benefiting various species within its environment.

questions.questionText: What is a distinctive feature of the beak of Falconiformes?
answers: A) They have a straight and sharp beak.
B) They have a hook-shaped beak for tearing leaves.
C) They have a beak with a tomial tooth.
D) They have a flat and wide beak for filtering water.

questions.questionText: In what type of habitat can peregrine falcons often be found?
answers: A) Only in Europe and America
B) Only in North America and Asia
C) On all continents including Antarctica
D) On all continents except Antarctica

questions.questionText: What adaptations do Falconiformes' wings have?
answers: A) Thin and pointed wings for speed and maneuverability.
B) Wide and rounded wings for slow flight.
C) Short and rounded wings for fast flight.
D) Long and flat wings for gliding.

birdInfo.description: It stands out for its light brown to brown plumage, with paler head and neck, and dark wing tips. It has a slender appearance and an upright posture, giving it an elegant look. It has a yellow hooked beak with a black tip and long yellow legs adapted for walking in search of food.
birdInfo.habitat: It inhabits open ecosystems, from grasslands, savannas, and agricultural lands to urban areas. It prefers open areas where it can hunt, but easily adapts to human-altered habitats, including cultivated areas and cities.
birdInfo.diet: Varied diet, omnivorous, feeding on small mammals, birds, reptiles, carrion, insects, other invertebrates, and fruits. It takes advantage of urban areas, feeding on waste and easily obtained food. It is an opportunistic bird, allowing it to survive in different environments.
birdInfo.reproduction: They nest in trees and palms, building large nests made of branches and other plant materials. The female usually lays 2 to 3 eggs, which are incubated for approximately 28 to 32 days. Both parents participate in feeding the chicks once they hatch.
birdInfo.size: Approximately 40-45 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Although it is a bird of prey, the Yellow-headed Caracara is often seen walking on the ground searching for food, which is unusual for birds of this type.
birdInfo.funFact2: This species has proven to be highly adaptable to urban environments, taking advantage of human resources, such as food waste, allowing it to thrive in populated areas.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Daptrius chimachima plays an important role as a scavenger, helping to clean the environment by feeding on dead animals and as a pest controller, as it consumes insects and small vertebrates. This bird helps maintain ecological balance by regulating prey populations and preventing the spread of disease through the elimination of carcasses.

questions.questionText: Which is one of the least common habitats for Falconiformes?
answers: A) Tropical forests.
B) Grasslands.
C) Deserts.
D) Underground zones.

questions.questionText: What type of prey do Falconiformes typically hunt?
answers: A) Mainly small birds, insects, and in some cases, small mammals.
B) Mainly large fish.
C) Mainly plants and nectar.
D) Mainly large terrestrial mammals.

questions.questionText: How do Falconiformes use their speed when hunting?
answers: A) To attack prey on the ground.
B) To search for prey in the water.
C) To catch prey during the night.
D) To perform fast and surprise attacks in the air.

birdInfo.description: It is an agile and fast bird of prey, with dark gray plumage and a black mask on its head. It is known for hunting in teams and using abandoned nests of other birds, as it does not build its own.
birdInfo.habitat: It prefers open areas like grasslands, savannas, and forest edges. It also inhabits plains, deserts, and regions near swamps, where it hunts in flight and finds shelter in trees or elevated structures.
birdInfo.diet: They feed on a variety of animals, insects, lizards, birds, and small mammals. They hunt insects and birds in the air or chase prey on the ground, often hunting cooperatively in pairs, with one bird scaring the prey and the other intercepting it.
birdInfo.reproduction: They nest in trees, palms, or on the ground, using beams of electric poles. They do not build their own nests, but instead occupy abandoned nests of other birds of prey, woodpeckers, or medium-sized birds. They lay 2 to 4 eggs and have one brood per season.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 38 and 43 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: It is one of the few falcons that hunts both solo and in pairs, increasing its efficiency in catching prey.
birdInfo.funFact2: Aplomado falcon pairs pass food to each other in mid-air. Sometimes the male passes food to the female easily; other times, he holds onto the food too long, and the female drags him in the air until he lets go.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Aplomado Falcon (Falco femoralis) plays an important role in its ecosystem as a population controller of small mammals, birds, and insects. As a top predator, it maintains the balance of the most abundant prey species and helps regulate food chains in grasslands and wooded areas where it lives. This reduces the overpopulation of certain species and contributes to the health of the ecosystem.

questions.questionText: What role do Falconiformes play in the biodiversity of their ecosystem?
answers: A) They decrease biodiversity.
B) They do not affect biodiversity.
C) They help maintain biodiversity by controlling prey populations.
D) They only affect the biodiversity of forests.

questions.questionText: How is the vision of Falconiformes compared to humans?
answers: A) Approximately equal to humans.
B) Approximately 1.5 times better than humans.
C) Approximately 2.6 times better than humans.
D) Approximately 5 times better than humans.

questions.questionText: What impact do Falconiformes have on small mammal populations?
answers: A) They increase small mammal populations.
B) They do not affect small mammal populations.
C) They regulate and maintain balanced small mammal populations.
D) They only affect large mammals.

birdInfo.description: The Colombian chachalaca, endemic to Colombia, as its name suggests, can be easily identified. All species have long tails.
birdInfo.habitat: The American Kestrel (Falco sparverius) prefers open areas with low vegetation and scattered trees, such as meadows, grasslands, deserts, parks, and agricultural fields. This species adapts well to human-modified habitats, such as pastures and urban parks, and is commonly found in cities, suburbs, and areas near human activity.
birdInfo.diet: American kestrels primarily feed on insects and other invertebrates, as well as small rodents and birds. Their usual prey includes grasshoppers, cicadas, beetles, and dragonflies; scorpions and spiders; butterflies and moths; voles, mice, shrews, and bats; and songbirds.
birdInfo.reproduction: These birds of prey lay their eggs in tree cavities, rock crevices, or other natural cavities. They may also use old woodpecker holes, nest boxes, or other human-made structures.
birdInfo.size: The American Kestrel is the smallest falcon in North America, measuring between 22 and 31 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Although it is small, the American Kestrel can carry prey weighing up to its own body weight.
birdInfo.funFact2: It is one of the few birds of prey that can hover in place while searching for prey, a behavior known as 'hover-hunting.'
birdInfo.bibliography: The American Kestrel (Falco sparverius) is an important predator that helps control insect and small mammal populations. In particular, they help control agricultural pests, benefiting farmers by reducing the need for pesticides.

questions.questionText: What characteristic of eagles makes them stand out when it comes to their nests?
answers: A) They build some of the largest nests in the world.
B) They build the smallest nests among raptors.
C) They never reuse their nests.
D) They prefer to build nests on the ground.

questions.questionText: What do many species of Accipitriformes, such as eagles, symbolize culturally?
answers: A) Destruction.
B) Isolation.
C) Power and majesty.
D) Fear and weakness.

questions.questionText: Why are Accipitriformes important to prevent the spread of diseases in the ecosystem?
answers: A) Because they feed on carrion.
B) Because they eliminate insects.
C) Because they purify water.
D) Because they control the population of smaller predators.

birdInfo.description: It stands out for its grayish plumage with dark bands on the tail and a barred belly. It has bright yellow eyes and long yellow legs. It is one of the most common raptors in Latin America.
birdInfo.habitat: In a wide variety of ecosystems, from tropical and subtropical forests to open areas, savannas, farmlands, and urban areas.
birdInfo.diet: It is an opportunistic hunter and its diet includes small mammals, birds, lizards, snakes, and large insects. It is observed hunting both from perches and in flight, and is known for actively hunting in open or semi-forested areas.
birdInfo.reproduction: It nests in trees, where it builds nests of sticks and branches. The female lays 1 to 2 eggs, which are incubated for approximately 30 days. Both parents participate in the care and feeding of the chicks, which leave the nest after about 40 to 45 days.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 33 and 41 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: It is a very adaptable species, which has allowed it to thrive in urban and rural areas, taking advantage of both natural prey and those associated with human activity.
birdInfo.funFact2: Unlike many raptors that rely on aerial hunting, the Roadside Hawk frequently hunts on the ground, chasing its prey on foot.
birdInfo.bibliography: This hawk plays a crucial role in controlling populations of small vertebrates and invertebrates. As a top predator, it helps maintain ecological balance by controlling rodents, lizards, and insects. Its presence in agricultural areas also makes it an ally for farmers, as it reduces rodent pests.

questions.questionText: What characteristic of eagles makes them stand out when it comes to their nests?
answers: A) They build some of the largest nests in the world.
B) They build the smallest nests among raptors.
C) They never reuse their nests.
D) They prefer to build nests on the ground.

questions.questionText: What do many species of Accipitriformes, such as eagles, symbolize culturally?
answers: A) Destruction.
B) Isolation.
C) Power and majesty.
D) Fear and weakness.

questions.questionText: What happens if the population of Accipitriformes in an ecosystem decreases?
answers: A) Prey decreases.
B) It does not affect the ecosystem.
C) Overpopulation of prey increases.
D) The food chain becomes more stable.

birdInfo.description: This large hawk, with black plumage on the head, reddish streaks on the shoulders, and a bright white chest, inhabits open and arid regions. It is shy, hunts small vertebrates and invertebrates, and avoids nesting near human activity and cultivated fields.
birdInfo.habitat: This hawk prefers open and semi-open grasslands or savannas, ranging from humid to arid areas, and adapts well to thorny and bushy plants. It dislikes cultivated agricultural fields but tolerates pastures for livestock that have not been overgrazed.
birdInfo.diet: It feeds on small vertebrates and arthropods, hunting from perches and in the air, primarily in the afternoon. It catches its prey with its feet, starting to eat them from the head, and the prey fed to the chicks are often headless and missing part of the torso.
birdInfo.reproduction: Its nests are typically roughly oval or elliptical, flat, and loosely constructed with dry branches, twigs, grasses, and herbs. It is known that pairs build 1 or 2 nests that they ultimately do not use, possibly due to human visits. They usually lay 2 eggs, sometimes 3, rarely 1 or 4.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 46 and 52 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: The long-winged eagle is known for its impressive flying abilities, which allow it to soar at great heights and cover extensive areas in search of prey.
birdInfo.funFact2: It is often seen perched on high points, such as trees or rocks, from where it has a panoramic view of its surroundings, making it easier to locate its prey.
birdInfo.bibliography: Geranoaetus albicaudatus, known as the white-tailed hawk, plays a crucial role in its ecosystem as a top predator. Its presence helps regulate populations of small mammals, birds, and reptiles, maintaining ecological balance. By hunting prey, it also contributes to nutrient dispersal through its droppings, promoting soil fertility.

questions.questionText: What is the main food source of the Black Vulture?
answers: A) Insects and small rodents
B) Fruits and seeds
C) Carrion, mostly large mammals
D) Fish and seafood

questions.questionText: Where do Black Vultures usually nest?
answers: A) High up in trees
B) In crevices between rocks or hollow trunks
C) In floating nests on lakes
D) Underground in burrows

questions.questionText: What ecological role does the Black Vulture fulfill?
answers: A) Disperses seeds to help regenerate forests
B) Controls populations of rodents and snakes
C) Helps clean the ecosystem by consuming dead animals
D) Contributes to pest control in urban areas

birdInfo.description: The pair is monogamous and maintains a long-term pair bond. They closely associate throughout the year and can feed their young up to eight months after fledging.
birdInfo.habitat: It is mainly found in open or semi-open habitats with abundant carrion to feed on, such as farms, savannas, grasslands, clearings, mangroves, and villages. It is associated with human settlements and feeds on streets, landfills, and around slaughterhouses.
birdInfo.diet: Primarily relies on carrion, mostly large mammals, but is opportunistic and easily scavenges trash, scraps, and other discarded edible waste. Occasionally consumes live prey. Food sources can be found in markets, slaughterhouses, fish-dumping areas, and garbage dumps.
birdInfo.reproduction: Typically nests in dark cavities or under some form of cover. Caves, hollow trunks, stumps, tree trunks, crevices between rocks, brush piles, shrubs, abandoned buildings, and sites next to or under trees and logs are all used. Almost always 2 eggs.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 60 and 68 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Instead of building a nest, the female lays her eggs on the bare ground of a cave, hollow tree, abandoned building, or other dark corner.
birdInfo.funFact2: There has been concern about the species' threat to aircraft, as well as its impact on personal property, public infrastructure, and especially agriculture, through the alleged predation of livestock.
birdInfo.bibliography: It has an important ecological impact as a scavenger, helping to clean the ecosystem by consuming dead animals. This prevents the spread of diseases and maintains balance in decomposition cycles. However, in some urbanized areas, its presence can increase due to the availability of garbage, which may create imbalances by competing with other scavengers and altering the natural dynamics of ecosystems.

questions.questionText: How does the adaptation of Cathartiformes to their habitat affect their social behavior?
answers: A) It prevents them from forming groups.
B) It allows them to find carrion faster in a group.
C) It forces them to hunt alone.
D) It reduces their flight ability.

questions.questionText: What is the main type of food for Cathartiformes?
answers: A) Fruits.
B) Insects.
C) Carrion.
D) Live fish.

questions.questionText: How do Cathartiformes contribute to the nutrient cycle in ecosystems?
answers: A) They help speed up the decomposition of organic matter.
B) They prevent competition between species.
C) They increase the population of insects.
D) They facilitate seed dispersal.

birdInfo.description: Both sexes show notable plumage dimorphism, though females are slightly larger than males. They have a narrow and sharply curved downward beak, with a concave culmen and sharp tip. It is a medium-sized bird of prey.
birdInfo.habitat: They are found in open freshwater wetlands, such as lake edges and marshes. They are often seen along roads and irrigation channels of rice paddies, where fences offer perches.
birdInfo.diet: It is a carnivorous bird that mainly feeds on aquatic snails, turtles, and small mammals. It searches for food in water patches and dives to catch snails with its feet, without getting its belly wet, at a depth of up to 16 cm.
birdInfo.reproduction: Nest building takes 4 to 18 days, though it can be prolonged if interrupted. Egg-laying is infrequent and usually consists of 2-3 whitish eggs with brown spots.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 42.0 and 46.0 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Males are responsible for most of the nest building as part of courtship, selecting the site, which is usually located over water to deter predators.
birdInfo.funFact2: Snail Kites often defecate after each meal, lowering their head and lifting their body and tail to a horizontal or slightly higher plane to do so.
birdInfo.bibliography: Rostrhamus sociabilis, commonly known as the Snail Kite, has several important ecological effects on its ecosystem: Control of snail populations: By primarily feeding on freshwater snails, the Snail Kite helps regulate their populations, contributing to the ecological balance of its aquatic habitat. This control of invertebrates is essential for maintaining the health of wetland ecosystems. Interaction with other organisms: As a predator, the Snail Kite plays a crucial role in the food chain. Its presence can influence the dynamics of other species, both as prey for birds of prey and other predators, and by controlling the populations of its prey. Ecosystem health indicator: The abundance and distribution of the Snail Kite can be indicators of the health of wetlands and freshwater bodies, as their well-being depends on a healthy aquatic ecosystem. Seed dispersal: Although its diet is predominantly carnivorous, the Snail Kite can also contribute to seed dispersal if it occasionally consumes fruits, promoting vegetation regeneration and diversity in its environment.

birdInfo.description: This medium-sized bird of prey, with black and white plumage and yellow legs and face, is easily identifiable when perched in high places. It is distinguished by its low flight and powerful wingbeats. Females are slightly larger, with a long tail and extended neck. Although it rarely soars, thermal currents can quickly lift it.
birdInfo.habitat: It inhabits a variety of open and semi-open areas below 3,000 meters in altitude, such as grasslands, savannas, pampas, and riverbanks. It prefers areas with scattered trees, posts, and fences for perching, especially near nesting sites. It avoids places with tall or dense vegetation that hinders takeoff from the ground.
birdInfo.diet: It feeds on insects, small vertebrates, eggs, and carrion, especially in winter. It hunts in open habitats such as grasslands, deserts, and human areas like agricultural fields and landfills. It searches for prey by walking, from perches, in low flight, or wading in shallow water.
birdInfo.reproduction: The Crested Caracara is the only member of Falconidae that builds its own nest, reusing or renovating previous structures. It nests in tall vegetation or similar structures offering a wide view. Both sexes participate in the construction, which lasts 2 to 4 weeks. They lay between 1 and 4 eggs, and both incubate for 32 to 33 days.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 50.0 and 64.0 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Adult pairs are generally monogamous and highly territorial, showing strong site fidelity.
birdInfo.funFact2: Caracaras use their beak to collect nesting material. They pull stems and vines while walking through grasslands, along fences, and ditches.
birdInfo.bibliography: -Population control: By feeding on a wide variety of animals, such as insects, small vertebrates, and carrion, it contributes to the control of these populations, maintaining ecological balance. Its role as a scavenger also helps remove dead animals, preventing the spread of diseases. -Nutrient recycling: By consuming carrion, the Crested Caracara contributes to nutrient recycling, speeding up the decomposition process and promoting ecosystem health. -Food chain interaction: As both a predator and scavenger, it influences the dynamics of other species by controlling prey populations and competing for carrion with other scavengers, like vultures.

birdInfo.description: It is characterized by its broad and short wings, adapted for flying in forests, and its massive migration in large groups.
birdInfo.habitat: Found in urban and suburban parks and gardens. It winters in older secondary forests and Amazonian forests.
birdInfo.diet: It mainly feeds on small mammals, birds, insects, and reptiles. Two essential characteristics are its ability to migrate long distances and its sharp vision for hunting.
birdInfo.reproduction: Pairs build the nest, with the female doing most of the work. Nests are often located on old nests from other species. The female performs most of the incubation, while the male provides food. Clutches usually consist of 3 or 4 eggs.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 34 and 44 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: The male may be able to complete incubation if the female dies.
birdInfo.funFact2: The male only visits the nest after transferring food to the female outside of the nest.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Buteo platypterus plays a key role in ecological balance. It controls populations of small mammals, birds, reptiles, and insects, regulating the food chain. Additionally, it contributes to soil fertility through nutrient dispersal via its droppings. Its role as a top predator maintains stability in the ecosystems it inhabits.

birdInfo.description: The pair is monogamous and maintains a long-term bond. They remain closely associated throughout the year and can feed their young for up to eight months after fledging.
birdInfo.habitat: It is mainly found in open or semi-open habitats with abundant carrion to feed on, such as farms, savannas, grasslands, clearings, mangroves, and towns.
birdInfo.diet: This bird primarily feeds on carrion, especially large mammals, but also scavenges for garbage and edible waste. It occasionally consumes live prey and can find food in markets, slaughterhouses, and landfills.
birdInfo.reproduction: It typically nests in dark hollows or under some type of cover. Caves, hollow logs, stumps, and tree trunks, rock crevices, brush piles, bushes, abandoned buildings, and sites beside or beneath trees and logs are all used. Almost always 2 eggs.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 60 and 68 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Instead of building a nest, the female lays her eggs on the bare ground in a cave, a hollow tree, an abandoned building, or another dark corner.
birdInfo.funFact2: There are concerns about the species' threat to aircraft, as well as its impact on personal property, public infrastructure, and particularly agriculture through alleged predation on livestock.
birdInfo.bibliography: It has a significant ecological impact as a scavenger, helping to clean the ecosystem by consuming dead animals. This prevents the spread of diseases and maintains balance in decomposition cycles. However, in some urbanized areas, its presence may increase due to the availability of garbage, which could cause imbalances by competing with other scavengers and disrupting the natural dynamics of ecosystems.

birdInfo.description: The Common Ground Dove is a small dove, slightly larger than a sparrow. Males are distinguished by their bright reddish plumage. Females are paler, tending more towards brownish than reddish tones, with black spots on their wings. All Columbidae pigeons temporarily store food in their crop. The grit in their gizzard is then used to grind the food later.
birdInfo.habitat: They are found in open, bare, and wet habitats such as wetlands, cleared areas, cultivated fields, gardens, riparian zones, and even suburban backyards, avoiding dense wooded areas.
birdInfo.diet: They primarily feed on seeds between 2 and 15 mm in length. Although it is a seed-eating species, it occasionally consumes snails and insects. They gather food by pecking seeds from the ground and swallowing them. They feed in small groups of up to 20 individuals.
birdInfo.reproduction: They build a nest of twigs in the treetops, where they lay two white eggs and can produce up to four broods a year.
birdInfo.size: They measure between 16.5 and 18 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Territorial Behavior: Columbina talpacoti is known to be quite territorial, especially during the breeding season. Males actively defend their area, even against other doves, to secure their mate and resources.
birdInfo.funFact2: Urban Adaptability: This species easily adapts to urban and suburban environments, being commonly seen in gardens, parks, and green areas. Its ability to live near humans has made it one of the most frequently seen birds in Latin American cities.
birdInfo.bibliography: Columbina talpacoti significantly contributes to the ecosystem through seed dispersal. By feeding on small seeds and fruits, it helps regenerate vegetation in its habitat, which is crucial for maintaining biodiversity. It is also part of the food chain, serving as prey for predators like hawks and snakes, helping to maintain balance in the food web.

birdInfo.description: The Colombian Chachalaca, endemic to Colombia as its name suggests, can be easily identified. All species have long tails.
birdInfo.habitat: It is found in humid forests, forest edges, and shrubland. The species is frequently observed at forest edges, gallery forests near crops, and pastures.
birdInfo.diet: The Colombian Chachalaca's diet is primarily frugivorous and folivorous. In a suburban forest in Valle del Cauca, its diet consists of 26 plant species, including fruits (77.2%), leaves (16.2%), and flowers (3.6%). Additionally, it occasionally consumes other elements like soil, dead leaves, and stones (3%).
birdInfo.reproduction: It is presumed to nest in a burrow in a ravine, often located in mature forests, sometimes near streams, or in landslide areas or road cuts. They lay 2 white eggs.
birdInfo.size: They measure between 45 and 60 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Although capable of flying, the Colombian Chachalaca prefers to move by hopping and running along branches and the ground, allowing it to navigate efficiently in its environment.
birdInfo.funFact2: The Colombian Chachalaca is social and is often seen in groups of up to 20 individuals. It is also known for its loud and raucous vocalization, especially during the morning and evening, helping with communication and territory defense.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Colombian Chachalaca plays an important role in its ecosystem as a seed disperser. By feeding on fruits and berries, it helps spread seeds, aiding the regeneration and maintenance of vegetation in the forests and semi-open areas it inhabits. It also serves as prey for various predators, integrating into the food chain and contributing to ecological balance.

birdInfo.description: This small-sized guan has distinctive plumage. Its body combines a bright chestnut belly, dark upper parts, brown neck and head, along with pale blue facial skin and red eyes. It is a stealthy and discreet species, tending to hide quickly when disturbed, and is generally silent, which helps it go unnoticed.
birdInfo.habitat: It mainly inhabits subtropical humid forests but is also found in low temperate areas, secondary forests, and coffee plantations, sometimes near roads.
birdInfo.diet: Its diet is primarily based on fruits, supplemented with seeds, flowers, leaves, and invertebrates. It feeds at dawn or dusk, lives in pairs or small groups, and is shy, spending most of its time in trees. It is rarely found on the ground.
birdInfo.reproduction: The female lays 2 to 3 eggs and incubates them without the help of the male. They build long, shallow nests in trees or epiphytic plants, using leaves and vines. They make neck movements to adjust the nest, possibly to roll the eggs and clean the nest.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 50.0 and 65.0 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: The black guan is very elusive and difficult to observe, spending most of its time hidden among the dense canopy vegetation of the forests.
birdInfo.funFact2: This bird performs a curious head and neck movement in its nest, which is believed to help roll the eggs and strengthen the nest's structure.
birdInfo.bibliography: -Seed dispersal: By feeding primarily on fruits, this species plays a key role in seed dispersal, helping to regenerate forests and maintain plant biodiversity. -Insect control: Although its diet is mostly frugivorous, it also consumes invertebrates, contributing to the control of insect populations in its ecosystem.

birdInfo.description: This is a medium-sized bird, with violet-brown plumage with pale gray areas, a green shine on the neck, a black beak, and red legs. It gathers in large numbers when food is abundant.
birdInfo.habitat: It inhabits forest edges, deforested areas, lake margins, rivers, and mangrove swamps. It prefers areas with abundant vegetation and is usually found high in trees, descending to the ground only to drink.
birdInfo.diet: The white-bellied pigeon is frugivorous, feeding on small black berries, but also consumes sand, grass seeds, and other seeds. It is often found perched on fruit-bearing trees.
birdInfo.reproduction: Their nests are small and fragile, made of twigs and located in trees or vines at several meters high, up to 15 meters. They lay a single white egg per clutch.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 29.0 and 34.0 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: -The white-bellied pigeon gathers in large numbers around abundant food resources, making it easier to observe in its natural habitat.
birdInfo.funFact2: -Its nest is surprisingly fragile, made of thin twigs, contrasting with the height it is often built, up to 15 meters above the ground.
birdInfo.bibliography: -Seed dispersal: These birds feed on fruits and seeds, helping the dispersal of plants in the forests where they live. By consuming the fruits and excreting the seeds, they facilitate the regeneration of vegetation in deforested or degraded areas. -Vegetation control: By consuming large quantities of seeds and fruits, they help control the growth of some plants, maintaining the balance in the ecosystems they inhabit.

birdInfo.description: It is a stealthy and discreet species, quickly hiding when disturbed, and generally silent, making it easy to go unnoticed.
birdInfo.habitat: It mainly inhabits subtropical humid forests but can also be found in low temperate areas, secondary forests, and coffee plantations, sometimes near roads.
birdInfo.diet: Its diet is primarily based on fruits, complemented with seeds, flowers, leaves, and invertebrates.
birdInfo.reproduction: The female lays 2 to 3 eggs and incubates them without help from the male. They build elongated and shallow nests in trees or epiphytic plants using leaves and vines.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 50 and 65 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: This bird is very elusive and difficult to observe, as it spends most of its time hidden among the dense canopy vegetation of the forests.
birdInfo.funFact2: This bird performs a curious head and neck movement in its nest, believed to help roll the eggs and strengthen the nest structure.
birdInfo.bibliography: This species disperses seeds by feeding on fruits, helping to regenerate forests and maintain biodiversity. By consuming invertebrates, it also contributes to insect population control in its ecosystem.

birdInfo.description: Rock pigeons are common in urban, suburban, and agricultural areas. Medium-sized, with a dark gray beak, they feed on corn or barley and drink by suction, using their beak like a straw, retracting their tongue to allow water into their mouth.
birdInfo.habitat: These birds nest in cracks and caves on rocky cliffs, whether by the sea or in inland highlands. Some populations have invaded abandoned buildings, especially near shrubland or agricultural areas.
birdInfo.diet: These birds feed primarily in the morning or late afternoon in open fields, pecking at seeds and fruits, and rarely invertebrates. In the presence of humans, they consume bread, popcorn, peanuts, and vegetable scraps, in addition to capturing larvae and slugs.
birdInfo.reproduction: Both sexes incubate, the male from mid-morning to late afternoon, the female from late afternoon to mid-morning, with both spending roughly the same amount of daylight hours on the nest.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 30 and 36 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Nest site selection is usually initiated by the male, who sits on the nest and calls to attract a mate. If the male dies, the female is likely to seek a new mate elsewhere. The site may be the former nest of a no longer present pair.
birdInfo.funFact2: Eggs are usually laid after the nest is finished or renovated. The first egg is laid in the late afternoon, and the second about 40 hours later.
birdInfo.bibliography: The rock pigeon (Columba livia), common in urban and rural areas, has diverse ecological effects. In the wild, it helps disperse seeds, contributing to plant regeneration. However, in urbanized areas, their large numbers can cause problems such as the accumulation of droppings, which deteriorates infrastructure and facilitates the spread of diseases. Additionally, by competing with native species for resources, it can affect local biodiversity and alter urban ecosystems.

birdInfo.description: It has been observed that these birds return to traditional roosting sites even after the trees have been cut down, where they may rest on the ground or in low bushes.
birdInfo.habitat: It inhabits arid to semi-arid shrublands, sometimes with scattered trees or irregular forests; it generally avoids tropical forests and is commonly seen in some large cities.
birdInfo.diet: It feeds on corn, wheat, rice, and soybeans, with only a small proportion of its diet consisting of wild plant seeds.
birdInfo.reproduction: It builds a small stick nest in a mangrove or small tree, or on the ground; it has even been found nesting on the roof beam of an abandoned farmhouse. The clutch size is usually two eggs.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 22 and 28 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: It has a high reproductive capacity, breeding several times a year and nesting in colonies, which facilitates its survival. This characteristic has made it a pest in some regions due to damage to crops.
birdInfo.funFact2: In Chile, this species is hunted for consumption.
birdInfo.bibliography: These birds help with seed dispersal by consuming them and excreting them, contributing to plant regeneration and maintaining ecosystem biodiversity. Additionally, as part of the food chain, they serve as prey for predators like hawks and sparrowhawks, helping maintain ecological balance. Their abundance makes them a reliable food source in rural and urban environments.

answers: A) Only in deserts

birdInfo.description: The Andean Motmot is a large bird with a thick black beak and a long tail with a racket-shaped tip. The body plumage is generally green, and there is a broad blue line bordering the crown, which is light blue in the front of the head and turns dark blue at the back. There is also a short black stripe in the center of the chest.
birdInfo.habitat: It is found in humid montane forests of the Andes Mountains in South America, from Colombia to southern Bolivia, often near rivers or streams, as well as in secondary forests and forest edges.
birdInfo.diet: This bird is omnivorous. It feeds on a variety of things such as fruits, invertebrates, and vertebrates. It feeds its chicks with 6cm moth larvae and 4cm beetles. There are also reports of frogs, lizards, and snakes.
birdInfo.reproduction: It is presumed to nest in a burrow in a ravine, often located in mature forests, sometimes near streams, or in landslide areas or road cuts. They lay 2 white eggs.
birdInfo.size: They measure between 45 and 60 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Andean Motmots have an unusual way of moving through the air. They make short flights and use their large wings to glide, allowing them to conserve energy and move efficiently through their forest environment.
birdInfo.funFact2: Their nesting habits are fascinating. They dig a horizontal tunnel in earthen embankments or banks, sometimes over 2 meters long, where they lay their eggs, making them one of the few bird species to nest in this manner.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Andean Motmot is an important species for its environment due to its diet, which helps control insect populations. Its role in dispersing seeds from the fruits it eats also contributes to forest regeneration and maintaining biodiversity in the Andes.

birdInfo.description: The male is black from forehead to nape with yellow spots on the crown and white spots behind. The female is distinguished by white spots on the head. It remains solitary, in pairs, or family groups and occasionally joins mixed flocks.
birdInfo.habitat: It is a species with a restricted distribution, found in edges of dry to moderately humid forests, second-growth shrublands, and wooded areas in northwestern Colombia. This small woodpecker is dull grayish-white and has a forehead and crown mottled with yellow and white.
birdInfo.diet: This species, which is exclusively insectivorous, can be found foraging alone or in small groups.
birdInfo.reproduction: The breeding season appears to be from January to June. It nests in cavities of dead tree trunks.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 9 and 10 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Endemic to Colombia: The Picumnus granadensis is endemic to Colombia, meaning it is only found in that country. It prefers to inhabit dry forest areas and mountainous regions, making it a very unique species in Colombian birdlife.
birdInfo.funFact2: Small Size and Adaptation: It is one of the smallest woodpeckers, measuring just about 10 cm in length. Despite its size, it displays typical woodpecker behavior, vigorously pecking at wood to find food, which is surprising given its diminutive build.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Picumnus granadensis, known as the Colombian Piculet, plays an important role in the ecosystem by helping control insect populations in trees, as it feeds primarily on larvae and insects found under the bark. By pecking at wood, it also creates cavities that can eventually be used by other species, such as small birds or insects, contributing to the biodiversity of its habitat.

questions.questionText: What structure do Piciformes birds excavate to nest?
answers: A) Nests on the ground
B) Underground tunnels
C) Cavities in tree trunks
D) Nests made of mud

questions.questionText: In what kind of areas do woodpeckers often live in urban zones?
answers: A) In parks and gardens
B) On house roofs
C) In open fields
D) In garbage dumps
