answers: A) Carnivorous
B) Herbivorous
C) Insectivorous and frugivorous
D) Piscivorous

birdInfo.description: The striped woodpecker is a large, crested woodpecker, mostly black, with a bright red crest, white bars on the underparts, and a white line extending down the neck. Males have red on the cheek, while females do not.
birdInfo.habitat: The striped woodpecker inhabits humid, transitional, and moderately dry forests and jungles. It generally prefers relatively open areas such as forest edges, secondary forests, and grasslands. It is not found inside lowland rainforests but occupies forest edges and riverine forests. In drier areas, it inhabits pine forests, gallery forests, and thorny scrublands.
birdInfo.diet: Its diet mainly consists of beetles and their larvae, ants and their larvae, caterpillars, and orthopterans, often collected from Cecropia trees. Although primarily insectivorous, it can be found alone or in pairs. In cities, it takes advantage of lamps to peck at them, amplifying the sound of its drumming to announce its presence and territory to other woodpeckers.
birdInfo.reproduction: The clutch size varies from 2 to 4 eggs. Both males and females take 2-3 hour shifts incubating during the day, but only males incubate at night. Chicks are fed about once an hour by both parents through regurgitation; the female does most of the feeding while the male guards the nest.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 37.7 and 41.8 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: They communicate through vocalizations, drumming, and pecking, especially during territorial defense.
birdInfo.funFact2: Both sexes excavate the nests, which are about 45 cm deep, 13 x 18 cm wide, and have an entrance about 9 cm in diameter.
birdInfo.bibliography: It plays an essential role in its ecosystem by controlling insect populations that live under tree bark, especially beetle larvae and other wood-boring insects, helping maintain forest health. Additionally, by drilling into trees to feed or nest, it creates cavities that other birds, small mammals, and reptiles can later use, increasing habitat availability and fostering biodiversity.

B) Passeridae

D) Columbidae

B) Carnivorous

birdInfo.description: It is easily recognized in flight by its loud and screechy calls, and when at rest, the striking blue head makes the species unmistakable. The birds migrate to islands near Panama after breeding in June.
birdInfo.habitat: Deciduous forest including cerrado, humid and very humid forest, mature second-growth forest, seasonally flooded forest, gallery forest, plantations, clearings, and semi-open areas with scattered trees, including Mauritia palm trees.
birdInfo.diet: Seeds of Albizia, Anacardium, Caraipa, Dialium, Hevea, Hura, Clusia, Ocotea, Couroutaria, Inga, Brosimum, Tectona, Micropholis; fruits of Tetragastris, Inga, Ficus, Euterpe; sugary flowers of Noranthea liana, among others.
birdInfo.reproduction: They nest in holes in palm trees, trunks, and dead branches. They lay two to four eggs, and in captivity, the incubation period lasts between 24 and 29 days. In captivity, only the female incubates.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 24 and 28 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Juvenile individuals usually have a less intense color, which becomes more vibrant as they mature.
birdInfo.funFact2: Unlike many other parrot species, the Pionus menstruus is known to be relatively quiet, especially when in flocks. Although it can occasionally make loud sounds, its discreet behavior helps it blend into its environment, avoiding predators.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Pionus menstruus, known as the blue-headed parrot, plays an important role in its ecosystem, mainly through seed dispersal when feeding on fruits, which helps regenerate vegetation and maintain the area's biodiversity. Additionally, it helps control pests by consuming insects and young shoots, helping to maintain the balance of the ecosystem.

questions.questionText: How does the role of Piciformes in seed dispersal affect ecosystems?
answers: A) It facilitates the regeneration of forests and biodiversity
B) It decreases the diversity of plant species
C) It causes deforestation
D) It reduces soil fertility

birdInfo.description: The Spectacled Parrotlet is a tiny parrot from eastern Panama, Colombia, and Venezuela. The male has a greenish-yellow forehead that extends to the cheeks and throat. This bird is not yet listed as a threatened species despite often being illegally captured and sold in the caged bird trade. The contact call is evidently used to communicate between members of a pair or group.
birdInfo.habitat: Found in the edges of evergreen lowland forests, gallery forests, semi-open deciduous forest, savannas, secondary growth, thorny scrub, grasslands, and clearings.
birdInfo.diet: Grass seeds extracted from the ground, berries, fruits, shoots, and likely flowers from shrubs.
birdInfo.reproduction: The nest is a hole in a stump, tree, or fence post made of bamboo (Guadua), often 1-2 meters from the ground, laying 1-6 eggs.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 12 and 13 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Small Size and Sociable Nature: The Spectacled Parrotlet is one of the smallest parrots in the Americas, measuring only 12-13 cm. Despite its size, it is very sociable and is found in large groups, which helps it stay safe from predators and facilitates food searching.
birdInfo.funFact2: Marked Sexual Dimorphism: There is a clear sexual dimorphism in this species: males have a striking blue color on the wings and behind the eyes, while females lack these markings, allowing them to be easily distinguished at a glance.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Forpus conspicillatus, known as the Spectacled Parrotlet, plays an important ecological role in seed dispersal. Its diet includes fruits and seeds, contributing to the regeneration of vegetation and maintaining biodiversity in its environment. It also helps control insect populations by consuming shoots and small invertebrates, which benefits the health of plants.

answers: A) Arid deserts

D) Tropical and subtropical forests

birdInfo.description: There is no sexual dimorphism. It is mainly green with a blue crown. On the forehead, it has a narrow and barely visible chestnut-colored band. Its tail is long, sharp, and green with a reddish tinge. Its beak is grayish-black. The facial skin and throat are bare and whitish, the wing feathers are bluish above. The inside of the wings is dull red.
birdInfo.habitat: The Chestnut-fronted Macaw is a colorful and widely distributed bird found in Panama, Colombia, Ecuador, eastern Peru and Bolivia, eastern Venezuela, and Brazil. This species has been recorded in various different habitats, including seasonally flooded forests, gallery forests, river edges rich in palm trees of slow-moving rivers, swampy areas, secondary growth, old plantations, and clearings with large scattered trees, areas temporarily or permanently wet with Mauritia palm trees.
birdInfo.diet: The diet of the Chestnut-fronted Macaw is also highly variable and includes seeds, pulp, and flowers from different types of plants. Unlike many other species of parrots and macaws, the Chestnut-fronted Macaw's populations appear to be stable.
birdInfo.reproduction: Generally nests in cavities of dead trees or dead palms. They lay two eggs; in captivity, incubation lasts 28 days, and the breeding period does not exceed nine weeks.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 46 and 51 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Great Adaptability to Different Habitats: The Severe Macaw is capable of adapting to a variety of habitats, from tropical forests to open areas and secondary forests. This adaptability allows it to find resources and survive in environments where other species might struggle.
birdInfo.funFact2: Playful and Noisy Personality: This species is known for its curious and playful personality. They are intelligent and very active birds, often seen exploring and manipulating objects in their environment. Additionally, they are quite noisy, emitting loud vocalizations that they use to communicate with each other and mark their territory.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Ara severus plays an important role in its ecosystem as a seed disperser. By feeding on fruits and seeds, it disperses a wide variety of plant species, helping forest regeneration and promoting plant diversity. It also contributes to the natural pruning of trees and branches, promoting healthy plant growth.

questions.questionText: Where do Psittaciformes generally nest?
answers: A) On the ground
B) In floating nests
C) In underground caves
D) In tree cavities

answers: A) Leaves and bark

birdInfo.description: Its name comes from the yellow on its forehead, characteristic of the superspecies group. It is a year-round resident in its range, although some birds may move due to food shortages, forming occasional flocks.
birdInfo.habitat: It inhabits deciduous tropical forests, thorny scrublands, humid gallery forests, flooded areas, mangroves, pine savannas, and cultivated lands with groves, mainly in the lowlands of Venezuela and Colombia.
birdInfo.diet: It feeds on fruits, seeds, and flowers of trees such as Pithecellobium, Acacia, and Ficus, as well as crops like corn, bananas, and guavas. It is usually seen in pairs or small flocks of up to 30 birds, though they can form flocks of up to 300 individuals.
birdInfo.reproduction: 2-4 eggs laid at 1-5 day intervals (usually two days); incubation 22-28 (average 25) days by the female alone, starting with the first egg.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 35 and 38 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Excellent mimic of human sounds in captivity, like other members of the same complex, and like them, there is evidence of regional dialects in this species.
birdInfo.funFact2: The main cause of reproductive failure in these birds is poaching by humans (77.8% of nests; 49 out of 63).
birdInfo.bibliography: Amazona ochrocephala, known as the yellow-crowned parrot, plays a vital role in its ecosystem by dispersing seeds. By feeding on a variety of fruits, it helps disperse seeds and facilitates the regeneration and diversity of vegetation in forests. Additionally, by consuming flowers and nectar, it also acts as an occasional pollinator, supporting plant reproduction.

questions.questionText: What feature distinguishes the feet of Piciformes birds?
answers: A) They have toes arranged in a zigzag pattern
B) They have five toes in total
C) They have two toes forward and two backward
D) They have long, thin toes

answers: A) Deserts and dunes

D) Mountain peaks

answers: A) Using their beak to drill and their long tongue to capture larvae hidden in tree trunks
B) Chasing larvae on the ground
C) Diving into water to catch aquatic larvae
D) Collecting larvae from leaves

birdInfo.description: It may benefit from forest clearing; its population tends to increase in areas where clearing and logging create more open forests. It is considered a local nuisance in plantations and gardens due to its fruit-eating habits.
birdInfo.habitat: These birds reside in both arid and humid habitats, such as coastal scrublands, dry forests, and urban areas. They prefer higher levels in wooded areas and lower levels in open spaces.
birdInfo.diet: Its diet consists of ants, beetles, larvae, orthopterans, spiders, and fruits such as papayas and bananas. They forage individually or in pairs at all levels of the forest.
birdInfo.reproduction: Nests in cacti, fence posts, and trees, being a solitary and territorial breeder. The clutch consists of 3-4 eggs, incubated by both sexes. Usually, 2 chicks are raised, which are fed and cared for by both parents for about 1 month.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 16 and 18.5 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Monogamous, they stay together all year but sleep individually in holes.
birdInfo.funFact2: Foraging techniques include hammering bark, probing, collecting from trunks, branches, and foliage, and reaching for fruits; it pierces the skin of larger fruits to obtain content.
birdInfo.bibliography: Melanerpes rubricapillus, known as the red-crowned woodpecker, has significant ecological impacts by contributing to pest control as it feeds on insects, including larvae that live under tree bark. Additionally, by excavating holes in trunks to nest, it creates cavities that can later be used by other species, such as smaller birds and mammals, enhancing nest site availability and promoting biodiversity.

questions.questionText: What is a distinguishing characteristic of Coraciiformes birds?
answers: A) Long, sturdy beak
B) Short, weak beak
C) Very small wings
D) Completely white plumage

questions.questionText: Where are Coraciiformes birds commonly found?
answers: A) Only in deserts

questions.questionText: How do they contribute to seed dispersal?
answers: A) They eat and digest seeds

C) They consume fruits and disperse the seeds in other areas
D) They destroy seeds

birdInfo.description: Large head with a striking, irregular crest that covers the entire crown from the base of the beak to the nape. The upperparts and wings are bluish-gray, except for the blackish flight feathers.
birdInfo.habitat: Inhabits along rivers, lakes, swamps, estuaries, water reservoirs, mangroves, and rice fields. It can be observed in wooded areas near the coastline.
birdInfo.diet: This bird is piscivorous and primarily feeds on fish, especially from the families Characidae and Cichlidae, though it also consumes frogs, salamanders, reptiles, crabs, and insects. It often perches on branches over the water, diving abruptly to catch its prey.
birdInfo.reproduction: Burrows are usually near water and are dug by both sexes, loosening soil with their beak and pushing it out with their feet. Excavation, which begins several days before laying eggs, lasts 4 to 5 minutes. They lay 3 to 6 eggs.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 38 and 42 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Incubating birds regurgitate (relaxed flow of stomach contents out through the mouth, often via belching) undigested fish scales and bones, attracting flies to the nest chamber.
birdInfo.funFact2: If prey is still alive, it will strike it against a hard surface to kill or stun it before consumption.
birdInfo.bibliography: Megaceryle torquata, the ringed kingfisher, has a vital role in freshwater ecosystems by controlling fish populations. By preying on small fish, the kingfisher helps maintain balance within aquatic food chains, preventing overpopulation of certain fish species, which could otherwise harm vegetation and invertebrates in their habitats.

questions.questionText: What is the function of the beak of Piciformes birds, like the woodpecker?
answers: A) To drill tree bark
B) To swim
C) To cut fruits
D) To catch insects in flight

answers: A) Arid deserts
B) Arctic zones

answers: A) Create holes in tree trunks that are later used by other species
B) Produce pollen for plants

birdInfo.description: Sexual dimorphism. The forehead is black, the crown is red, the sides of the head are white, bordered below by a red mustache (only in males). Females lack the red mustache below the white sides of the head. Its preference for more open forests means it is not heavily affected by logging.
birdInfo.habitat: This species inhabits diverse environments, including rainforests, deciduous and gallery forests, as well as secondary forests, mangroves, swamp edges, plains, and open lands with large trees. It can also be found in scrublands, clearings, moriche palm groves, and coffee plantations.
birdInfo.diet: They feed on ants and their larvae, living in pairs or family groups. They forage on trees at medium and low heights and also descend to the ground to search for food in ant nests. In trees, they use gleaning, probing, and pecking techniques, while on the ground, they probe and sweep the leaf litter.
birdInfo.reproduction: Nests consist of holes excavated by both sexes in the trunks of dead trees at medium or high heights, sometimes in fence posts. During close encounters, they display rocking movements and shake their heads and extended tails.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 18 and 21 centimeters in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Ground Foraging Behavior: Unlike many other woodpeckers, the spotted-breasted woodpecker often forages on the ground, digging for insects and ants, which is an unusual behavior for most woodpecker species.
birdInfo.funFact2: Drumming Communication: This species uses a behavior called drumming, which consists of repeatedly tapping on tree trunks with its beak. This sound is used to mark territory and attract a mate, serving as an important form of communication within the species.
birdInfo.bibliography: Colaptes punctigula contributes to pest control by feeding on insects and larvae found in tree trunks and soil, benefiting the health of trees and reducing pest proliferation. Additionally, by drilling tree trunks to create nests, it generates cavities that can later be used by other species, such as birds and small mammals, promoting fauna diversity in the area.

questions.questionText: What characteristic distinguishes songbirds from the order Passeriformes?
answers: A) Their monochromatic plumage
B) Their large size
C) Their ability to produce complex melodies
D) Their habit of hunting insects

questions.questionText: What percentage of all bird species do songbirds represent?
How does the presence of songbirds affect the perception of an ecosystem's health?
answers: A) The presence of songbirds has no impact on the ecosystem's health
B) The presence of songbirds is irrelevant to the ecosystem's health
C) Their absence indicates a more balanced ecosystem
D) Their song and presence indicate a healthy and balanced environment

birdInfo.description: It is a medium-sized species, olive-brown above with two white wing bars, a pale gray chest, and a pale yellow belly. Yellow-bellied elaenias have a bushy and striking crest that is often raised when the bird sings, revealing a white patch on the crown. They are usually found alone or in pairs.
birdInfo.habitat: Variety of moist and arid habitats, wooded areas including open forests, secondary forests, and edges, thickets, savannas, as well as river margins with brush, clearings with brush and scattered trees, also trees in towns and gardens; absent in densely forested areas. They may gather in greater numbers in fruit trees.
birdInfo.diet: Feeds on insects, berries, and arillated seed capsules, foraging with aerial sallies, pecking from perches.
birdInfo.reproduction: Breeding season in Colombia occurs between May and September. The nest is a tidy cup of grass or moss, lined with feathers and decorated with lichens and bark, placed in the fork of a small branch. The clutch consists of two eggs, rarely one or three, white-pink with brown and gray markings. Incubation by the female lasts 16 days; chicks are fledged by the female and fed by both parents, fledging period is 15-17 days.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 16 and 17 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: It is known for its characteristic crest that it can raise, showing a yellowish tone, visible when excited or alert.
birdInfo.funFact2: Its song is very distinctive and repetitive, making it easily identifiable in its habitat, especially during the breeding season.
birdInfo.bibliography: Elaenia flavogaster plays an important role as a seed disperser, consuming a variety of fruits and helping plant propagation by excreting seeds in different areas. It also contributes to insect control, as its diet includes insects that it catches in flight, helping maintain balance in the ecosystem's food chain.

D) Increase the use of special glass in buildings and regulate lighting

birdInfo.description: Males of common tody-flycatchers have bright black foreheads, slate-gray rear crowns, olive upper parts, black wings, and bright yellow underparts; the iris is generally yellow.
birdInfo.habitat: All types of open and semi-open areas and forest edges, mangroves, and rivers, such as clearer forests, regrowths, clearings, and pastures with grown thickets, shaded plantations, open groves, savanna thickets, hedgerows (rows of trees and/or shrubs), orchards, gardens, cultivated areas, wastelands; avoids densely forested regions.
birdInfo.diet: Arthropods, including small ants and parasitoid wasps, spiders, beetles, bugs, flies, damselflies, and grasshoppers or crickets; they also gather fruits. Generally found in pairs or family groups, but sometimes alone and usually independent of mixed flocks in dense vegetation near the ground, also in mid-levels and tree canopies, more open.
birdInfo.reproduction: Builds hanging pouch-shaped nests 1 to 5 m from the ground made of plant material, mosses, grasses, and many other plant materials, bound with spiderweb, lined with fine grass, feathers, and plant down/seeds; suspended from a hanging branch (or even a telephone wire), usually at 1-5 m but sometimes up to 30 m high, sometimes near a wasp nest. Clutch of 2-3 eggs; incubation by the female alone, lasting 18 days; chicks fed by both parents, nesting period about 17-18 days.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 8.8 and 10.2 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Forages in pairs or small family groups in dense vegetation near the ground or mid-level tree canopies.
birdInfo.funFact2: Partially dependent on parents for up to 43 days, benefits from deforestation, spreading into clearings and plantations, where it is often common.
birdInfo.bibliography: Todirostrum cinereum plays an important role as an insect population controller, feeding primarily on them, including mosquitoes, ants, and other small insects. This helps maintain balance in the ecosystem and reduce the proliferation of pests. Additionally, by consuming small fruits and dispersing seeds through its droppings, it helps regenerate and diversify vegetation in its habitat, contributing to the health of the ecosystem where it lives.

answers: A) They have no impact on pest control

answers: A) Small to medium
B) Large
C) Very small
D) Giant

birdInfo.description: Males and females differ notably in color; the vermilion crest and bright underparts of the male contrast sharply with the whitish, slightly streaked chest and pinkish belly of the female.
birdInfo.habitat: They inhabit arid scrublands, farmlands, parks, golf courses, deserts, savannas, cultivated lands, and riparian woodlands; prefer open spaces with nearby perches. They are rarely found in densely forested areas.
birdInfo.diet: Insectivorous, catching prey in mid-air after watching from a perch. Flies back to the perch to consume prey or feeds from the ground.
birdInfo.reproduction: The nest is a cup of fine grasses, weeds, feathers, and other materials, placed in a tree or shrub, often near water. Lays 2-4 eggs. Incubation lasts 14-15 days, mainly by the female. Chicks fledge in 16-19 days.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 13 and 15 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: They are known for their striking coloration, especially in males, which stand out against arid and desert backgrounds.
birdInfo.funFact2: They have a characteristic hunting method called 'flycatching,' where they remain on a perch and then dart out to capture insects in mid-flight.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Vermilion Flycatcher plays a vital role in controlling insect populations in its habitat, contributing to the natural balance of ecosystems. This insectivorous species reduces populations of insects, especially flying insects, which can otherwise become pests. Its striking coloration makes it a popular species for birdwatching, contributing to ecotourism and increasing awareness of the importance of conserving natural spaces.

questions.questionText: What is the main purpose of song in songbirds?
answers: A) Attract predators
B) Find food
C) Protect from harsh weather
D) Mark territory, attract mates, and coordinate behaviors

questions.questionText: How do songbirds contribute to ecosystems?
answers: A) Only as predators
B) Only as prey
C) As seed dispersers and pest controllers
D) Only as food competitors

questions.questionText: What role do songbirds play in the ecological balance of the region?
answers: A) They only serve as food for other species
B) They only affect local vegetation
C) They only participate in pollination
D) They maintain the ecological balance through their singing and their role in the ecosystem

birdInfo.description: Both sexes and plumage are similar throughout the year. Adults have wide white and black stripes on the head, with black crown and mask contrasting with white supercilium. Chin and throat are white, with remaining underparts bright yellow. Their distribution and abundance have increased due to forest openings through various human activities.
birdInfo.habitat: Inhabits thorn forests, tropical deciduous forests, tall chaparral, riparian forests, gallery forests, palm swamps, marshy lake edges, shaded coffee plantations, bananas and citrus groves, forest edges, and rural, suburban, and urban areas with trees. Often absent from uninterrupted habitats, whether arid thorn scrub or tropical rainforests, except along watercourses or other edges.
birdInfo.diet: Feeds on a variety of arthropods, mollusks, and small vertebrates, including flying insects, spiders, snails, small fish, lizards, and mice. It also consumes fruits and visits feeding stations for food such as bread and bananas. Hunts from low perches, generally less than 3 meters from the ground, and often strikes its prey, such as fish, before swallowing.
birdInfo.reproduction: Builds bulky nests, often in thorny swamp trees or on abandoned nests of other birds. Pair formation occurs year-round but is most common before and at the beginning of the nesting season. Clutches usually consist of 2 to 5 eggs, generally 3 or 4. Only the female incubates the eggs for 15-17 days, facing the nest entrance.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 27.2 and 29.9 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Often steals nesting material from abandoned or unwatched nests of other birds. Nests are mainly built from grass, but may also incorporate thin twigs, woody vine tendrils, paper, cotton, rags, and even plastic trash.
birdInfo.funFact2: About 1 day before fledging, chicks stand at the nest entrance and flap their wings, causing the nest's roof to collapse.
birdInfo.bibliography: This bird inhabits a wide variety of ecosystems, from urban areas to forests and rural zones. Ecologically, it plays a key role in insect control, feeding on a wide range of insects and helping maintain their population balance. Additionally, it disperses seeds by consuming fruits, contributing to vegetation regeneration and biodiversity in its habitat. As an adaptable bird, it significantly contributes to the balance and health of the ecosystems it inhabits.

questions.questionText: What is a key strategy for protecting songbirds?

B) Use of pesticides in their habitats
C) Elimination of nature reserves
D) Reduction of national parks

B) Encouraging bird trafficking
C) Discarding existing laws
D) Reducing surveillance in bird markets

questions.questionText: What is a way to mitigate the impact of invasive species on songbirds?
answers: A) Ignoring their presence
B) Introducing more invasive species
C) Allowing the proliferation of invasive species
D) Eradicating or controlling invasive species

birdInfo.description: Sexual dimorphism is not very pronounced. It has a very long and deeply forked tail (shorter in females). It has a black crown, nape, and sides of the head extending below the eyes. The back is light gray, the wings are darker, the tail is black, and the underparts are completely white.
birdInfo.habitat: Found in open habitats, including forest edges, secondary vegetation, savannas, grasslands, residential areas, meadows, forests, cerrado, and mangroves. During migration, it can be found in a wide variety of habitats, including the canopy of tall, humid forests.
birdInfo.diet: Searches for flying arthropods (e.g., termites, beetles, wasps) or picks them from leaves or the ground; also consumes fruit such as palm berries during the non-breeding season.
birdInfo.reproduction: Breeds from January to May in Colombia. The nest is a shallow cup made of plant fibers, leaves, and lined with fine fibers, rootlets, feathers, and cotton-like materials such as seed fluff. It is placed 1 to 10 meters high in a tree or shrub. The female lays 2 glossy white eggs, irregularly marked with chocolate and purple, mainly on the crown. The incubation period is 14 to 15 days. The chicks stay in the nest for about 16 days.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 37.0 and 40.5 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Tyrannus savana is famous for its acrobatic flight. It performs aerial maneuvers to catch insects and also during the mating season, making it highly attractive and spectacular.
birdInfo.funFact2: These birds are migratory and can travel long distances. They breed in North America and then migrate to South America for the winter, covering thousands of kilometers.
birdInfo.bibliography: Tyrannus savana plays an important role in its ecosystem as an insect controller. These birds feed primarily on flying insects, helping regulate their populations and maintaining the ecological balance. Additionally, by moving through various areas during migration, they participate in seed dispersal, contributing to vegetation regeneration in different habitats.

questions.questionText: What strategy should be adopted to protect the migratory routes of songbirds?
answers: A) Reduce international collaboration
B) Ignore resting and feeding areas
C) Protect resting, feeding, and breeding sites along the routes
D) Destroy migratory routes

questions.questionText: What aspect of songbird singing indicates a balanced and biodiverse environment?
answers: A) The intensity of the song
B) The variety and frequency of the song
C) The duration of the song
D) The clarity of the song

questions.questionText: In what types of habitats can songbirds be found?
answers: A) In a wide variety of habitats, from forests to urban areas
B) Only in deserts
C) Exclusively in mountainous areas
D) Only in cold zones

birdInfo.description: The head, nape, and back are almost uniformly brown: darker and more reddish in eastern populations, paler and grayer in western ones. It has only a pale, often indistinct, superciliary line and no crown streaking. The throat and chest are uniformly light gray, sometimes with a beige or brownish tinge. Both sexes have identical plumage, and immature birds resemble adults. Unlike other wrens, its diet includes many seeds and fruits, and it is known to feed on vegetable matter and even kitchen scraps.
birdInfo.habitat: Inhabits forests, scrublands, forest edges, and urban areas, preferring places with dense vegetation. It nests in tree cavities or human-made structures such as walls, houses, or gardens. It can also be found in gardens, parks, and any green space near buildings or urban areas.
birdInfo.diet: Feeds on a variety of arthropods, small insects, and spiders. Additionally, it is known to feed on fruits, seeds, and occasionally small invertebrates.
birdInfo.reproduction: Builds its nest in cavities, using materials such as leaves, feathers, and twigs. The female lays 3-8 eggs and incubates them for 12 to 15 days. The chicks are altricial, meaning they are born helpless and are fed by both parents.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 11.5 and 12.5 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: It is one of the most familiar birds in gardens, parks, and rural areas. Its song is complex and melodious, consisting of varied and high-pitched whistles.
birdInfo.funFact2: This species has adapted remarkably well to human presence, often nesting in buildings, walls, and urban gardens.
birdInfo.bibliography: The house wren plays a crucial role in its ecosystem as a pest controller. By feeding on a variety of arthropods, it helps regulate populations of insects, spiders, and other small invertebrates. Additionally, its song is often an indicator of a healthy and biodiverse environment, as it thrives in a variety of habitats, including forests, gardens, and urban areas.

questions.questionText: How do songbirds contribute to forest regeneration?

birdInfo.description: Both sexes are similar. They are olive-brown above, paler below, with a slightly darker face, whitish throat with brown stripes, and whitish belly from the middle to the cloaca. Their beak and legs are black. They are common in urban and semi-urban areas, often seen hopping on lawns searching for worms and invertebrate prey.
birdInfo.habitat: Found in clearings, semi-open areas, savannas with gallery forests, and lighter secondary forests. It also inhabits forest edges, shade coffee plantations, disturbed areas, and various early succession habitats. You can also find them in pastures with shrubs, parks, gardens, urban and semi-urban areas, and town edges.
birdInfo.diet: Granivorous, frugivorous, and insectivorous. They feed on nuts, insect larvae, beetles, flies, berries, fruits, seeds, crickets, and caterpillars. Insects are more important during the dry season in Colombia. Common and visible in areas occupied by humans, they move in pairs or individuals. They hop on the ground in meadows and generally in open areas or shrubs, although they are also seen visiting fruit trees or areas with more vegetation.
birdInfo.reproduction: Reproductive activity is recorded between December and August and October in Colombia, where the season seems to vary by region. Nests are placed in hedges, pastures, secondary forests, and around human dwellings. Nests have been found in bushes, stumps, tree forks, and similar situations, usually below 5 meters, with an average height of around 2.5-3 meters. They lay 2 or 3 eggs, which are bluish-green with dark brown spots. The incubation period is poorly documented but is estimated to last between 13 and 15 days.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 18.5 and 24.0 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Turdus ignobilis is known for its melodious and varied song, used both for communication and territory marking, being one of the most vocal birds in its environment.
birdInfo.funFact2: Although primarily found in forested areas, this bird has adapted well to urban and rural environments, where it can be seen foraging in gardens, parks, and green areas near human settlements.
birdInfo.bibliography: Turdus ignobilis plays an important role in its ecosystem by dispersing seeds from the fruits it consumes. This contributes to the regeneration and propagation of plants and trees in its habitat, promoting biodiversity. Additionally, it feeds on insects and small invertebrates, helping to control their populations and maintain ecological balance.

birdInfo.description: Its common name comes from the large amount of yellow in its plumage, with black restricted to the tail, a narrow yellow bib, and wings.
birdInfo.habitat: In the Caribbean region, primarily in arid to semi-arid forests and shrublands, with cacti, mesquite, and acacias. It frequents open forests and gallery forest edges, and also cultivated lands with trees and shrubs, riparian habitats, fallows, parks, and gardens in cities, cultivated areas, and forest plantations, but prefers dry areas rather than humid regions. It is the most common Troupial in the Santa Marta area, even in mangroves.
birdInfo.diet: Mostly small insects, beetles, flies, butterfly, and moth larvae, with some cicadas and grasshoppers. Other arthropods include spiders and wind scorpions. It also feeds on Barbados cherry and date palm fruits. It takes nectar from the flowers of Erythrina fusca and Pithecellobium saman trees. Generally seen in pairs or small groups.
birdInfo.reproduction: Apparently monogamous and territorial. They build elongated pouch-shaped nests hanging from tree branches, mainly woven from plant fibers, particularly grasses and palm fibers. Clutch usually consists of 2 to 3 eggs, which are bluish-white with dark purple markings, primarily at the broader end.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 20.0 and 21.0 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: It is the national bird of Venezuela and is appreciated for its striking yellow and black plumage, as well as its melodious and varied song.
birdInfo.funFact2: This species is known for its opportunistic behavior, as it can use abandoned nests of other birds or even steal materials from other nests to build its own.
birdInfo.bibliography: It plays an important ecological role as a seed disperser, as it feeds on fruits and helps plant propagation in its environment. Additionally, it consumes insects, contributing to the control of their populations and maintaining the ecosystem's balance.

birdInfo.description: The Green Honeycreeper is a small, brightly colored bird. One of its most distinctive features is its slender, slightly downward-curved yellow beak. Males are bright bluish-green with a wide black mask, while females are duller green.
birdInfo.habitat: This species is found in humid and tropical forests, especially in the canopy, as well as secondary forests and coffee plantations with shade. They are commonly seen in mixed-species flocks, moving quickly through the foliage.
birdInfo.diet: Its diet includes fruits, especially berries, and it also consumes insects and nectar from flowers. It has a preference for ripe fruits, which it uses to aid seed dispersal. It occasionally forages for insects in the foliage of trees.
birdInfo.reproduction: Reproductive activity is typically observed between February and August. They build cup-shaped nests, often in trees or bushes, using fine plant materials. The female lays 2-3 eggs, which are incubated for about 12-14 days. Both parents participate in feeding the chicks after hatching.
birdInfo.size: It measures about 13.0-14.0 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: The Green Honeycreeper is part of the tanager family and is known for its vibrant plumage and active foraging behavior in the treetops.
birdInfo.funFact2: This bird can often be seen with other species of tanagers in mixed flocks, sharing feeding areas and moving together through the forest canopy.
birdInfo.bibliography: The Green Honeycreeper contributes to its ecosystem by dispersing the seeds of the fruits it eats. It also plays a role in controlling insect populations, maintaining a healthy balance in its habitat. Its preference for nectar also makes it an occasional pollinator.

birdInfo.description: The Saffron Finch, known for adapting well to human-modified habitats, is common in its range. It is a medium-sized bird with short wings and tail, and a large beak. The male has yellow plumage with orange tones on the head and spots that extend to the throat and face, along with greenish tones on the wings and tail. The female is similar but with duller colors and less orange on the crown, and a less intense yellow on the abdomen. Males often sing from a branch, a post, or a power line.
birdInfo.habitat: Wide variety of habitats, generally semi-open with scattered trees or shrubs, including dry open forests, savannas, thorny scrub, Chaco forests (forests with non-floodable grassland areas), edges of swamps and water bodies, gallery forest edges, roadside scrub, secondary growth, and agricultural areas; also meadows in towns.
birdInfo.diet: Seeds, also small arthropods. It forages on the ground, often in urban meadows. Found in pairs and small flocks.
birdInfo.reproduction: The nest is a voluminous semi-sphere made of dry grasses, lined with softer material, including hair, placed in palm leaves or a cavity, such as a pipe or roof eave. Clutch of 2 to 4 eggs, cream-colored with violet-brown markings.
birdInfo.size: Measures between 13.5 and 15.0 cm in length.
birdInfo.funFact1: Male Sicalis flaveola have striking bright yellow plumage, especially during breeding season, while females have duller colors for better camouflage.
birdInfo.funFact2: This species adapts very well to urban and rural environments and is often seen in human-inhabited areas, building nests in roofs, artificial structures, or even nest boxes.
birdInfo.bibliography: Sicalis flaveola plays an important role in its ecosystem by consuming seeds, contributing to the dispersal and control of plants and weeds. It also feeds on insects, helping regulate populations of these invertebrates and maintaining ecological balance in its habitat.

birdInfo.description: It is a large nocturnal bird with big yellow eyes. It often perches on branches, fence posts, or exposed limbs where its cryptic coloration helps it avoid detection. It is more frequently identified by its eerie, descending call and is typically solitary.
birdInfo.habitat: They inhabit the rainforests of the Neotropics, living in forest edges, humid and very humid areas, and also open areas near water bodies, plantations with scattered trees, forest edges, gallery forests, and mangroves.
birdInfo.diet: They feed at night by perching on exposed branches and catching flying insects. They remain upright, watching attentively with frequent head movements until they spot a large insect. The insects are caught mid-air and then the bird often returns to the same perch.
birdInfo.size: It measures between 33 and 38 cm in length.
birdInfo.reproduction: It is believed that the common potoo is monogamous; both sexes are said to incubate the egg and care for the chick. They lay a single egg, which is incubated on top of a broken branch or stump, or in a slight depression on a large tree limb.
birdInfo.funFact1: It remains still during the day. It perches on high branches, usually in an upright posture. When not alarmed, it perches more vertically with its bill pointed forward instead of upwards.
birdInfo.funFact2: When it suspects it’s being watched, it stretches its body, compresses its plumage, and raises its head, all so gradually that no movement is detected. It may use the same roosting spot for months.
birdInfo.location: Eco-park Lago de Las Garzas, University of Valle, Club Campestre Farallones
birdInfo.bibliography: Nyctibius griseus plays a crucial ecological role in its ecosystem. As a nocturnal insect predator, it helps control pest populations, contributing to the balance of the food chain. Additionally, by consuming insects that could harm vegetation, it indirectly protects local flora. As part of the trophic web, it also serves as prey for larger predators, making it an important component of the ecosystem's biodiversity.
